data.title: Shahjehan - M-e-A , some parallels
data.text:
Though the characters of sangtarash/but-tarash are purely fictional

there are many things which are common in both the movies .

In Shahjehan we find a but-tarash coming all the way from Iran

Shirazi ( Jairaj )and in the ensuing competition for Roohi ( Nasreen )

he creates a mujassima of Roohi . Unfortunately it was turned down since

it was un-islamic . The poet Sohail ( KL Saigal ) wins but in a strange

bid to save the life of Roohi being hit by an arrow he himself gets

killed .

Meanwhile not withstanding the defeat Shirazi presents a

miniature model of Tajmahal and wins both the hearts of Shahjehan and

Roohi . Shirazi and Roohi get married .

Shahjehan had also a role

similar to Suraiya in M-e-A . 2 songs were picturised on her singing

with rabab in hand with Azurie dancing .

1.jab usne gesoo bikhraye and

2.jawani ke daman ko rangeen banale ( both in Shamshad's voice )

IMO Naushad scored an excellent music in both the movies .

I would give a 5 star rating and add one more if there is a provision .

Was K ASif inspired by his senior AR Kardar ?

- kp

Interesting parallels no doubt. But there are significant

differences. Shirazi is one of the two principal

male characters in "ShahjahaaN", whereas M. Kumar has only

a peripheral role in "M-e-A", as the "saNg~taraash".

Jairaj in "ShahjahaaN" was more of an architect, than a

mere sculptor. Even Saigal "builds" a paradise on earth :

"Kar leejiye chal kar meri jannat ke nazaare.."

The two songs mentioned by you were filmed on Bengali

actress Salochana Chatterjee, who (even then) was a bit

on the plus side. She acted in many Hindi movies e.g.

"Paras", where she was Rehman's lady-love. I also

remember her in "Baazuband", where she was the erring

Balraj Sahni's long-suffering wife.

I would definitely give Naushad's music a much higher

rating in "ShahjahaaN". Somehow I have always felt that

the music in "M-e-A" was not of the standard one expected

from a music genius like Naushad.

Afzal

I don't know what Naushad is talking about. He was

working for other banners since quite early. Rattan (1944)

was not a Kardar film. Nor was Anmol Ghadi (1946).

On a different note, Anil recently mentioned that only

Mohd Ibrahim has been credited (in some film titles) as

Naushad's assistant. I don't know how correct that statement

is. For the new (and maybe the old as well) release of

M-e-A, Shafi's name is mentioned with Ibrahim's.

HFGK mentions Ghulam Mohammed's name as assistant

for Natak (1947) which means it is officially documented

either in HMV's files or in the film title or both.

actually shafi and ibrahim are both credited as assitants in the

i think nani's remark elsewhere about naushad's quality deteriorating

terms of listening quality between M-E-A and Kohinoor. but i guess

lata can make even the ordinary songs sound like spectacular

compositions.

i prefer the naushad of the andaz, amar, anmol ghadi genre rather than

his later works. in fact andaz and amar are truly masterpieces in my

opinion. even those who dont like naushad will acknowledge that.

When I wrote : "Anil recently mentioned that only

Mohd Ibrahim has been credited (in some film titles) as

Naushad's assistant", I wasn't referring to you (Anil

Dixit) but to Anil De.

As for my statement that Ghulam Mohd has been mentioned

as asst in HFGK for Natak (1947), I remember Hamraaz

telling me that in the second edition of 1950s Kosh, names

of assistants have been mentioned using HMV's documents

as source. But for most 1940s films, film titles are used as

source of information when it comes to mentioning assistants

whenever it was possible for him and his team to have access

to a film's print. That should mean that in case of 'Naatak',

Ghulam Mohd's name was mentioned in film credits, though

it is just a strong guess, not an item confirmed beyond doubt.

I agree with Pasupuleti Garu that music of M-e-A is superb.

I would give it at least 4 stars and won't mind giving it

all 5. I like music of Shabab and chorus songs in Amar

as well. I find Lata's solos in Amar and Uran Khatola boring.

From Amar onwards, Naushad's quality declined. YMMV.

But M-e-A is an exception. Its songs have great warmth

of feeling. Normally, Afzal Sahab tends to take Naushad's

side but he was disappointed by M-e-A's music. M-e-A

causes role reversal in me, too. I would take M-e-A's songs

over Anarkali any day. Anarkali's music is not upto the

standard I expect from C Ramchandra - Lata pair.

- dn

Good to find some change in you and Anil too .

M-e-A was released on Aug 5 , 1960 in Hyderabad but the 78 rpm

discs were relesed for sale only on Aug 14 , and I remember on

Aug 15 , 1960 what everyone heard on Independence day almost on

every street cornor were only songs from M-e-A . What a day

to remember . The discs were sold in 3 days and many had to

wait for days to get them .The only 2 discs which remained unsold

in large quantity were the thumri's of Bade Ghulam Ali Khan and

the boring Rafi solo ' zidabad zindabad '

We spent 3 hours of our time in mughal durbar the movie goers

who came out of the show commented .The background music was

something beyond description .

In a repeat when the show was aired on DD in 1993 there were

many sponsers for every song except the 3 songs mentioned earlier .

M-e-A was a history as far as the music goes .Wonder why Naushad

was denied an award for music .
